docs.snippet: One of Somalia's warlords sent an urgent letter to President Bush shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States telling him that there were terrorists in Somalia sympathetic to Osama bin Laden.     The warlord, Hussein Mohammed Aidid, ad...
docs.lead_paragraph: One of Somalia's warlords sent an urgent letter to President Bush shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States telling him that there were terrorists in Somalia sympathetic to Osama bin Laden. The warlord, Hussein Mohammed Aidid, advised Mr. Bush that Al Barakaat, the country's major money-transfer and telecommunications company, had ties to terrorists as well. He said he would be willing to help the United States in any way he could.
docs.abstract: Clan rivalries are so bitter in Somalia that US cannot accept at face value accusations by one warlord that another has ties to terrorists; US, acting on advise of Hussein Mohammed Aidid, a warlord, has shuttered al Barakaat, Somalia's major money-transfer and telecommunications company, for trafficking in terrorist money, and it has named Al Itihaad, militant religious group based in Somalia, as terrorist organization with ties to Al Qaeda; does not recognize interim government of Pres Abdiqassim Salad Hassan, and American officials suspect that some people close to it may have connections to Al Itihaad (M)

headline.main: Somalia's Multitude of Factions Hinders Antiterror Efforts
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: TRACKING AL QAEDA

docs.snippet: The Pentagon is strongly considering plans to send large numbers of American ground troops into a mountainous area of southern Afghanistan to help search for Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader, senior Pentagon officials said today.    The pl...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon is strongly considering plans to send large numbers of American ground troops into a mountainous area of southern Afghanistan to help search for Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader, senior Pentagon officials said today. The plan calls for hundreds of ground troops, most likely marines, to assist forces allied with Gul Agha Shirzai, the American-backed warlord who controls the Kandahar region, in attacking about 2,000 Taliban soldiers thought to be hiding near the town of Baghran in Helmand Province, the officials said.
docs.abstract: Pentagon says it weighs sending American ground troops to mountainous area of southern Afghanistan to help forces allied with Afghan warlord Gul Agha Shirzai search for Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar; plan calls for hundreds of troops, probably marines, to help in attacking about 2,000 Taliban soldiers thought to be hiding near Baghran and shielding Omar; over 20 American Special Forces soldiers leave Kandahar, apparently to join up to 30 other Special Forces soldiers aiding Shirzai; Special Forces troops are involved in brief skirmish, near Jalalabad; photos (M)

headline.main: U.S. Might Send Ground Troops To Assist in the Search for Omar
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: SEARCH FOR MULLAH OMAR

byline.original: By JAMES DAO with NORIMITSU ONISHI

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Nicholas D. Kristof (column, Dec. 26) calls for an amnesty for Mullah Muhammad Omar, arguing that his responsibility for crimes in Afghanistan should be overlooked to promote peace.     But recent Afghan history is filled with le...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof (column, Dec. 26) calls for an amnesty for Mullah Muhammad Omar, arguing that his responsibility for crimes in Afghanistan should be overlooked to promote peace. But recent Afghan history is filled with leaders from all sides who have committed egregious acts with impunity.
docs.abstract: James Ross letter on Nicholas D Kristof's Dec 26 column opposes amnesty for Mullah Muhammad Omar; drawing

docs.snippet: The leaders of two Afghan tribal factions battling for control of Gardez, in the east, have gone to Kabul at the request of the government for peace talks. Fifty fighters were killed when forces from the different clans attacked last week, raising...
docs.lead_paragraph: The leaders of two Afghan tribal factions battling for control of Gardez, in the east, have gone to Kabul at the request of the government for peace talks. Fifty fighters were killed when forces from the different clans attacked last week, raising questions about the ability of the government to impose its authority. It was not immediately known when their talks in Kabul might begin. For now, a cease-fire is holding.
docs.abstract: Leaders of two Afghan tribal factions battling for control of Gardez go to Kabul at government's request for peace talks; cease-fire is in effect (S)

docs.snippet: John Walker, whose spiritual quest, prosecutors say, led him to fight against his fellow Americans in Afghanistan, returned to the United States today  and is scheduled to appear in court on Thursday in Virginia.    Mr. Walker arrived at Dulles In...
docs.lead_paragraph: John Walker, whose spiritual quest, prosecutors say, led him to fight against his fellow Americans in Afghanistan, returned to the United States today and is scheduled to appear in court on Thursday in Virginia. Mr. Walker arrived at Dulles International Airport outside Washington shortly after 6 p.m. and was flown by helicopter to the Alexandria Detention Center.
docs.abstract: John Walker, American who fought with Taliban in Afghanistan, is returned to United States for trial; arrives at Dulles International Airport as officials seek to underscore that he is under civilian, not military, control (M)

headline.main: Walker Is Returned to U.S. And Will Be in Court Today
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN PRISONER

docs.snippet: As American military advisers traveled to meet Philippine Army units that are battling Muslim guerrillas on a southern island, a senior Philippines official said here today that President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo rejected an offer from President Bu...
docs.lead_paragraph: As American military advisers traveled to meet Philippine Army units that are battling Muslim guerrillas on a southern island, a senior Philippines official said here today that President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo rejected an offer from President Bush in November to send American combat troops to join directly in the fighting. ''President Bush said, 'We are offering American forces to fight in the Philippines,' '' Defense Minister Angelo Reyes said. ''He said that in the White House. I was there.''
docs.abstract: American military advisers travel to meet Philippine Army units, and Defense Min Angelo Reyes of Philippines reveals that Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo rejected offer from Pres Bush in Nov to send American combat troops to join directly in fighting Abu Sayyaf, Muslim guerrillas who have been linked to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network; Philippines Constitution prohibits foreign soldiers from fighting on nation's soil; opposition leaders says Macapagal Arroyo should be impeached for violating Constitution (M)

headline.main: Philippines Said to Have Refused Bush Offer of G.I.'s in November

docs.snippet: When the new government in Afghanistan begins to rebuild, it will have its choice of places to start. Simon Norfolk, a British photographer, captured some of the rack and ruin around the capital using a Wista, a large-format camera that produces p...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the new government in Afghanistan begins to rebuild, it will have its choice of places to start. Simon Norfolk, a British photographer, captured some of the rack and ruin around the capital using a Wista, a large-format camera that produces pin-sharp 4-by-5-inch negatives. War photographers routinely return home with more than a hundred rolls of 35-millimeter film, but Norfolk shot just 120 frames during his two-week stay in Afghanistan. TV Mountain (top left): On Oct. 8, an American airstrike destroyed the radio and TV transmission towers, silencing the Taliban's Voice of Shariah radio broadcasts from Kabul. What would turn out to be the last radio transmission from TV Mountain declared that Taliban commanders would ''fight until their last drop of blood against the United States and other invaders.''
docs.abstract: Photo article on destruction in and around Kabul, Afghanistan

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 1-06-02: GALLERY

headline.main: Saying Goodbye to a Green Beret

docs.snippet: Eight commanders and generals sat in a circle in a rocky ravine, as hundreds of their fighters watched from nearby crags and hillsides. The peaceful scene ended the latest bout of fighting here in northern Afghanistan, a five-day clash between the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eight commanders and generals sat in a circle in a rocky ravine, as hundreds of their fighters watched from nearby crags and hillsides. The peaceful scene ended the latest bout of fighting here in northern Afghanistan, a five-day clash between the Northern Alliance and a local leader trying to regain power. It ended with negotiation and without bloodshed, as directed by top officials of the alliance's Defense Ministry. By satellite telephone, they stressed the need to avoid any more fighting.
docs.abstract: Clash between Afghanistan's Northern Alliance and Sayed Jaffar, local leader of Ismaili people, ends peacefully; his representative meets with alliance and says he erred in marching with hundreds of troops on Pul-i-Khumri in bid to regain power; he offers to surrender, then flees with all his soldiers and residents of Kayan, his home village; his deserted headquarters show clear signs of recent United States special forces presences; Alliance has charged US backed Jaffar and called airstrikes against its forces when they opposed his move on city; holds Jaffar tricked Americans into thinking they were attacking Taliban; photo (M)

headline.main: Clash With Afghan Group Ends With Talks, Bloodlessly

docs.snippet: Pakistan said yesterday that the United States had not consulted it about the possibility of American-led forces crossing into Pakistan to hunt down Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters. Maj. Gen. Frank Hagenbeck told reporters in Afghanistan last week t...
docs.lead_paragraph: Pakistan said yesterday that the United States had not consulted it about the possibility of American-led forces crossing into Pakistan to hunt down Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters. Maj. Gen. Frank Hagenbeck told reporters in Afghanistan last week that United States forces might cross into Pakistan to snuff out the extremists' havens. But a Pakistani military spokesman, Maj. Gen. Rashid Qureshi, insisted there had been no such request from the United States-led forces. General Qureshi said Pakistan's policy was clear: ''All actions that are to be taken inside Pakistan are taken by Pakistani forces and Pakistani personnel.''
docs.abstract: Pakistani Maj Gen Rashid Quereshi says United States has not sought permission for American-led forces in Afghanistan to cross into Pakistan to hunt down Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters; insists all actions inside Pakistan must be taken by Pakistani forces (S)
